coredata.dc:creator: Sundheim, Benson R.

coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A molecular dynamics computation on a model of K2MgCl4 wherein the ionic interactions involve only central forces is reported. The predominant structure is a very well defined trigonal MgCl− 3 ion cluster. The Raman spectrum is discussed in terms of the potential of average force.

WOODCOCK* Department of Chemistry, University of Southampton, Southampton, UK Received 24 April 1972 A molecular dynamics computation on a model of K2MgCI4 wherein the ionic interactions involve only central forces is reported. The predominant structure is a very well defined trigonal MgCI3 ion cluster. The Raman spectrum is discussed in terms of the potential of average force. The Raman spectrum of a fused salt solution consisting of one mole of magnesium chloride and two moles of potassium chloride (K2MgCI4) displays four more or less resolved Raman bands, one of which is partially polarized [1, 2] . The experimenters concluded that this spectrum apparently arose from the tetrahedral species MgCl~‘. Support for this conclusion was drawn from comparison with the Ramai‘ spectra of other divalent species, namely, CdCl~‘, PbCl~, and HgCl~‘, as well as from heat of mixing results. The tetrahedral structure proposed for K2MgCI4 was also proposed for the K2MgBr4 arid K2MgI4 and appeared to be the principal species in solutions where the halide to magnesium ratio varied from 3 to 5. In halide complexes of transition metal ions, the geometry and coordination number are presumably the result, in part, of angle-dependent interactions with the central ion reflecting its electronic structure. Group LIA ions, however, would not be expected to show angle-dependent interactions with ligands. Consequently, the specific structure of a complex species in a fused salt presumably comes about through the interplay of coulombic (plus hard core) forces, the * Ramsay Memorial Fellow. packing in the liquid state and the vagaries of thermal motion. It is not immediately clear how any such species finds itself in an environment which is of definite geometry for long enough to lead to fairly sharp Raman lines. One would like to know whether nondirectional pair-potentials when combined with the exigencies of packing at liquid densities can, in principle, produce a model system which will give Raman lines or whether the occurrence of Raman lines implies “chemical“, i.e., directional, bonds. The details of the average structure and fluctuations about the average for a plausible, though simplified, model of the fused salt, are accessible to molecular dynamics modeling on a computer. We report here on such calculations and on the properties of the liquid found in this way with particular emphasis on their implications for the interpretation of the Raman spectrum. The volume and temperature were adjusted to the required values, and the dynamic computations resumed. Stabilization of the first order properties indicated that equilibrium had been reached in less than 10—12 sec, and the final configuration was used to initialize the production run. These computations were performed at intervals of 5 X 10—15 sec for a total of 2.5 X 10—12 sec. The second (production) run computation was made at steps of 1.0 X 10—14 sec for a total time of 5.0 X 1012 sec. When the equilibrium configuration of a species as determined by the minimum in the potential energy curve is characterized by a given symmetry, one may expect that the motion of the system may be described as a superposition of displacements corresponding to the irreducible representations of the symmetry of the potential energy functions. It is clear that one must be very cautious in attributing any conventional interpretation to force constants which may be calculated in these circumstances. We may also note that it is possible in principle to compute the polarizabilities of the species found in the dynamical calculations and use them to predict the intensities of the Raman lines. A closer analysis (in progress) of the shape of the potential of average force and of the nature of the fluctuations around this quantity should make it possible to make quantitative predictions about the shape of Raman lines. Comparing with the experimental observation of four Raman lines, one polarized, there seems to be a significant discrepancy.
